This is a direct result of Trump’s tariffs and excessive crack down on illegals.Politics under Trump seems to be above the law, there is no accountability, unqualified people are being placed into government positions simply because they are Trump friendly. Political corruption has increased significantly. Public schools are now worse than they were before as Trump has cut funding even more, so if your a parent that wants to get your kid a good education, you’ll have to invest heavily in private schooling which increase most US citizen expenses to $1500/mo just to get their kid educated thru High School, not even started on college funding yet.Trade concerns and the massive increase in the deficit has my retirement investments all over the place with huge fluctuations making me extremely nervous. After Trumps 21% tax cut for corporations and the 1% richest people in and out of America, the stock market got a bump to about 25000 and is now stuck fluctuating between 23000 - 26000 and hasn’t seen any stable positive trend/growth. So much for the so called corporate world “re-investing” in America, they just took the tax cut money and built more factories in Asia.Trump is now targeting Social Security as the next program to cut … what’s going to happen to the all the money I’ve paid into Soc Sec over the past 35 years, will it be there when I need it? I’ve paid A LOT of money into Soc Sec. Trump has just added more stress to my world.These are the REAL affects of Trump’s changes on our lives.

The USA has changed less than you’d think since Donald Trump’s election. The sun still rises and sets. People still sleep, eat, work, and learn. The roads still roll, the power still runs, and the cold water is still cold. As for how it’s changed? Well, the economy has kept humming along, still generally on or a little below Obama’s trendline. Trump is disrupting this—but I’ll get back to that. Socially it’s mixed. Racism and homophobia are more overt again, but the backlash against sexism a la Trump is finally bringing more shreds of social equality to women. Institutionally we’re in trouble. The GOP has been trash-talking government for decades, and right now too many Republicans are willing to undermine too many long-standing pillars of society, from law enforcement to the courts to our independent press to many portions of the Constitution. Internationally we’re in trouble too. Trump has made our word next to worthless, what with pulling out of treaties and accords for either bad reasons or trumped-up reasons. He scorns and undercuts diplomacy while worshiping the cult of war—war for other people to fight, not him and his family. When the US withdraws, it does not lead. We are rapidly abandoning our leadership role globally, and our still-new trade war is leading to other countries cutting us out of the commerce equation. That means shocks for our economy. Right now the primary hope for the country is a solid repudiation of Trump. We need to rebuke his mean-spiritedness, his divisiveness, and his incompetence. We need to expose, debunk and reverse his demagogic, anti-populist, anti-Christian, anti-Constitutional platform that’s wrapped up in a cloak of flag-hugging, Christianist, propagandist gaslights. I wish I could say that I’m hopeful.

It hasn’t changed, just more stuff is out there in the open. Context: The last 10 years have been very volatile in the U.S.There have been multiple movements aimed at shaking things up since the financial crisis:The Tea Party MovementOccupy Wall Street MovementThe Intersectionality Movement (or Modern PC Movement)Trumpism (Populism)The ResistanceThe Progressive Movement (Bernie Bros)Alt-Right MovementThese movements have all been a product of changes in the United States, ranging from economic to political issues that haven’t really been addressed by the 2 parties.On the right, Trumpism was a product of the failure of the Tea Party movement to a. get rid of Obamacare and b. force Obama out of office during the 2012 election. The base thought Republicans weren’t fighting the Dems hard enough on issues, and started referring to weak Republicans as “cuckservatives.” Trump came about due to the strong demand for an unprincipled brawler, who could offer what the Tea Party failed to offer and more.4 out of the 5 movements on the left are still active. All somewhat represent the total triumph of the New Left coalition from the 1970’s over the Labor/Socialist/Welfarism segment of the Left going all the way back to the 1930’s, who ultimately achieved nothing during the OWS Movement. The politics of the left is increasingly focused on identity issues.The Alt-Right Movement, differs somewhat from Trumpism and is already on the decline, but as a movement, it is still important. It’s really the first movement on the right to see some sort of usefulness of identity politics. It’s dying mostly because identity politics, by its nature doesn’t unite, but rather balkanizes people.The Intersectionality Movement is in competition with the Resistance for attempting to unite the left or better yet to develop somekind of structure around identity politics. The Intersectionality movement is trying to provide a hierarchical structure for the Left so that it can prioritize the needs of it’s diverse base (the more oppressed you are, the more your political needs matter and should be prioritized.) The Resistance is more a left-wing version of the Tea Party that is aimed at getting rid of Trump, but doesn’t really have anything to offer besides that.Lastly, the New Progressive Movement, is a product of the Dems realization after watching Trump, that the country is a lot more open to government intervention in the economy (despite the failure of this branch of the left to get anything done during OWS). It’s also a product of the realization that millennials are much more open to some socialism since they are convinced that they will not have the same quality of life as their parents.In other words, both parties are still trying to deal with the crash of 2008 and it’s cultural impact that led to an increasing frustration with the institutions of the U.S. Trumpism has managed to distract his base and the GOP from this, by going all out on the Culture war and fights over Tariffs, whereas the Democrats are still trying to figure out how to manage all the diverse interest groups that make up their coalition, and how to deal with the conflicts of interest. Their division is what enabled Trump to win the last election.

Trump’s importance can be overstated. I have plenty of friends, very educated friends, stateside who really don’t pay much attention to him. I have to make sure that I don’t raise him in my conversations with them, for fear of coming across as a bore or a crank! They seem to have (or “seem to have had” - I haven’t spoken to them since before the Shutdown, just humorous exchanges on a WhatsApp thread) a general perception that he is not good for America but really only talk about it when something big breaks the headlines - (Putin, Trump & Helsinki) did that for them. You have to remember that 50% of the States don’t bother to vote. I am sure that at least most of my friends do - but I guess they work off general principles, rather than personalities. I think the impact he is having now is the drama of a reality TV show. If, like me (sadly and much to my own bemusement), you are the kind of person that will race home to make sure you don’t miss an episode and perhaps set your recorder just in case you run late or something else happens to make you miss a bit - or you just want to rewatch! - then Trump will feel to you as if deep changes to the fabric of American and global life are being made. In practice, the wrinkles - and some deep creases and the odd tear - that Trump has made in the Constitution will begin being ironed out from January 21st 2021 and by November 2025 there will still be stuff to do and some echoes to damp down, but generally Trump’s significance will have been reduced to a road bump and that will wear down further over time as well. He is just not an able enough politician to make lasting changes to America. He is all personality and no substance. There is of course an ‘unknown’: Will GOP continue chasing the Alt-Right for votes? If so, the lasting legacy of 2016 - 2020 may be the radicalisation of GOP and the fracturing of the 250-year GOP/Dem binary Constitution. If that happens - the US Government will move more central in terms of politics (a little closer to western Europeans - bear in mind that the majority of Americans who vote, vote Dem and that the majority is urban) and the current form of right-wing politician will be out of power for a very long time to come. ALTERNATIVELY - America moves even further right until the current Alt-right becomes a US version of ISIS! DISCUSS!
